verses.text: Do not envy evil men, nor desire to be with them;
verses.comment: The warning not to envy the wicked is frequent in wisdom literature because worldly success is temporary. Compare also Psalm 37:1-2.

verses.text: for their hearts plot violence, and their lips speak of trouble.
verses.comment: The nature of the wicked is inward evil (heart) and outward trouble (lips). Jesus later teaches on the heart as the source of evil (Matt. 15:18-19).

verses.text: By wisdom a house is built, and by understanding it is established;
verses.comment: True stability comes from wisdom and understanding, symbols that Christians later see fulfilled in Christ, the foundation of the Church (cf. Matt. 7:24-25).

verses.text: by knowledge the rooms are filled with all precious and pleasant riches.
verses.comment: Riches in this context refer to both material and spiritual blessings achieved through rightly ordered knowledge.

verses.text: A wise man is strong; a person of knowledge increases in strength.
verses.comment: True strength is rooted in wisdom and knowledge, pointing to the importance of ongoing growth in the faith.

verses.text: For by wise guidance you wage your war, and in an abundance of counselors there is victory.
verses.comment: Victory in life’s battles comes from wise guidance, reflecting a principle of authority and submission to godly counsel (see Acts 15:6).

verses.text: Wisdom is too high for a fool; he does not open his mouth in the gate.
verses.comment: The fool is excluded from deliberations at the city gate (symbolizing judgment and leadership), as true authority comes from wisdom.

verses.text: Whoever plans evil will be called a schemer.
verses.comment: Planning evil carries a social condemnation—what is hidden will be named openly (cf. Matt. 10:26).

verses.text: The devising of folly is sin, and the mocker is detested by people.
verses.comment: Sin begins in the heart, and scoffing or mockery is held as especially dangerous (see 2 Pet. 3:3).

verses.text: If you faint in the day of adversity, your strength is small.
verses.comment: Spiritual strength is especially proven in adversity, as seen in the lives of saints and Christ Himself (Heb. 12:2-3).

verses.text: Rescue those who are being taken away to death; hold back those who are stumbling to the slaughter.
verses.comment: This verse commands active intervention against injustice—often seen as a biblical mandate for protecting the innocent (cf. Matt. 25:40).

verses.text: If you say, 'See, we did not know this,' does not he who weighs the hearts perceive it? Does not he who keeps watch over your soul know it? And will he not repay every man according to his deeds?
verses.comment: God’s justice is comprehensive—He weighs the heart and will judge every work (cf. 2 Cor. 5:10). This verse hints at the doctrine of eternal reward and judgment.

verses.text: My son, eat honey, for it is good, and the drippings of the honeycomb are sweet to your taste.
verses.comment: Honey represents the sweetness of wisdom and God’s Word (see Ps. 119:103), a theme fulfilled in Christ as the Bread of Heaven (John 6:51).

verses.text: So shall you know wisdom is such to your soul; if you find it, there will be a future, and your hope will not be cut off.
verses.comment: The pursuit of wisdom is a guarantee of lasting hope—anticipating the Christian understanding of the hope found in salvation (1 Pet. 1:3-4).

verses.text: Do not lie in wait, wicked man, against the home of the righteous; do not destroy his resting place;
verses.comment: The fate of the righteous is protected by God, a theme echoed in the security of the faithful throughout Scripture.

verses.text: for though a righteous man falls seven times, he rises again, but the wicked stumble in the time of calamity.
verses.comment: The perseverance of the righteous displays God’s grace, supporting the doctrine of ongoing spiritual growth and restoration (see Phil. 1:6).

verses.text: Do not rejoice when your enemy falls, and let not your heart be glad when he stumbles,
verses.comment: Mercy toward enemies prefigures Christ’s teaching in the Sermon on the Mount (Matt. 5:44).

verses.text: lest the Lord see it and be displeased, and turn his anger away from him.
verses.comment: God values sincere hearts and humility above outward victory, calling for compassion and restraint.

verses.text: Do not fret because of evildoers, and do not envy the wicked,
verses.comment: The repetitive warning against envying the wicked appears throughout Scripture, as their prosperity is fleeting.

verses.text: for the evil man has no future; the lamp of the wicked will be put out.
verses.comment: The ‘lamp’ is a biblical symbol for life, legacy, and spiritual illumination (see Matt. 25:8).

verses.text: My son, fear the Lord and the king, and do not join with those who are given to change;
verses.comment: Respect for both divine and civil authority is commanded; orderly government reflects a God-given hierarchy.

verses.text: for disaster will arise suddenly from them, and who knows the ruin that will come from both?
verses.comment: Judgment may fall quickly on those who rebel against established authorities—see Numbers 16:32-35.

verses.text: These also are sayings of the wise: To show partiality in judgment is not good.
verses.comment: Calling for impartiality anticipates later New Testament teaching on justice and equality before God (Rom. 2:11).

verses.text: Whoever says to the wicked, 'You are righteous,' people will curse him, nations will abhor him;
verses.comment: Perverting justice brings a universal condemnation. God's law transcends local customs.

verses.text: but those who rebuke the wicked will have delight, and a good blessing will come upon them.
verses.comment: The blessing on just correction echoes the responsibility of spiritual leadership to uphold truth.

verses.text: Whoever gives a right answer kisses the lips.
verses.comment: Righteous words are as intimate and valuable as a loving kiss, suggesting the value of truth in relationship.

verses.text: Prepare your work outside; get everything ready for yourself in the field, and after that build your house.
verses.comment: Prioritize wisely—spiritual preparation precedes edification, a model imitated in stages of Christian initiation and discipleship.

verses.text: Do not be a witness against your neighbor without cause, and do not deceive with your lips.
verses.comment: Echoes the ninth commandment, reinforcing God’s demand for truth and justice in social life.

verses.text: Do not say, 'I will do to him as he has done to me; I will pay the man back for what he has done.'
verses.comment: Condemns revenge and foreshadows Christ’s teaching on forgiveness (Matt. 5:38-39).

verses.text: I passed by the field of a sluggard, by the vineyard of a man lacking sense,
verses.comment: Laziness is rebuked throughout Proverbs as incompatible with a life of wisdom.

verses.text: and behold, it was all overgrown with thorns; the ground was covered with nettles, and its stone wall was broken down.
verses.comment: Disorder and ruin are the result of sloth, a visual reminder of the consequences of original sin.

verses.text: Then I saw and considered it; I looked and received instruction.
verses.comment: Wisdom is learned by observing the world and drawing right conclusions.

verses.text: 'A little sleep, a little slumber, a little folding of the hands to rest,'
verses.comment: The repeated phrase is a proverb about the subtlety and danger of laziness.

verses.text: and poverty will come upon you like a robber, and want like an armed man.
verses.comment: Neglect of duty leads inevitably to ruin—materially and spiritually. The spiritual life requires diligence as seen in the lives of the saints.
